Title: What is the best way to start making money online with affiliate marketing?
Body:
No, not even close to the best way.
Say you’re promoting a store that sells novelty electronics. Every customer you send makes you say 15% of the sale. Who gets the other 85%? These novelty electronics items are most likely manufactured in China and purchased in bulk $2 to be sold for $20. People who want to get rich try affiliate marketing and now and then some get lucky and manage to make enough money and learn enough about the system to actually move on to getting rich. People who already understand how business online works get people who want to get rich to make them rich. You start a store, join an affiliate network as a merchant, and you get rich off of affiliate marketers trying to get rich. Its never the person promoting other people’s work, products or ideas who get rich it is those who manipulate others into doing their work for them.

Now say you want to get rich, forget everything you’ve learned about affiliate marketing. Study the markets themselves. Look at what the other side, the merchants/advertisers are doing. See if you can find where they are getting their products (a simple google search for bulk amounts of a specific product they sell on their site can find a supplier), look how they market their business, look for what they use to encourage others to promote their business for it.

I used to own almost a dozen of those “paid survey” aka GPT sites and even started an advertising network running offers on dozens more of those sites. I was on track to earning 6 figures a year from them, but I got hit hard with a lot of fraud (and a good portion of that fraud although seemingly from Vietnam I have reason to believe it was committed by the very company that was the number one source of fraud prevention in the industry at the time) and I lost pretty much all of it. What I didn’t lose I sold off to cover the losses and the money I had left over I had 2 options: Start over or move on. I didn’t have the stomach for it, I didn’t like the idea of carrying on getting people to make me money by telling them they’d somehow get rich from it. Now I do web design and marketing as a side business, property management, and spend my extra time on some various projects I’m working on. The point is, the question you should be asking is how can you get the affiliate marketers to work for you.

An affiliate marketer that invests a couple thousand dollars can make a decent living. Someone who invests $5k into starting something up and then hiring affiliate marketers can make a fortune. I had to go to every site I could find, research everything thing I could get my hands on, investigate every part of the business and the other business owners weren’t exactly eager to share their secrets. So, the answer is no and the answer you didn’t ask for is this: No one who can teach you how to make a lot of money online will, and anyone who says they can teach you just wants you to make a lot of money for them.

Title: How can I generate website traffic with $0 marketing budget?
Body:
Well, if that's the case - no cash for acquiring customers 2 days ahead of the launch - then I hope you will learn a very hard lesson for your next startup :(

If it makes you feel any better - you're not alone. We all made this mistake at some point.

There are only two vehicles you can instrument to reach your audience. Money and time.

Money gets you instant traffic/leads, and from that point on, the game simply boils down to finding a positive ROI channel before you burn all your (or your investor's) cash. On the flip side - I wound't recommend spending money at this point anyhow, as you most probably don't know your quintessential customer yet, nor you have clear understanding on their perceived value for your product/service. As a result, you're unable to craft the right marketing lingo that would be used to carry out your campaigns. Essentially, you would be just pouring money down the drain.

Now, back to the topic - if you don't have the money, you simply have to invest the most valuable resource you have in your life. Your time.

The trick with this (and the lesson you probably learned by now) is you cannot invest the time two days ahead of your launch, with no money left in the bank. You have to start investing T - 1 year. Why? Because it takes time to build your reach and credibility.

Building reach and credibility is the most successful way to establish relationship with your customer base, yet it is the most difficult one at the same time. Clearly, that is why everyone would love to take the shortcut, i.e. spend marketing dollars to the same effect.

Here's an example I'm genuinely amazed with, a "hack" Buffer (company) did to build their reach and credibility.

By riding the hype of developing a culture of transparency, and blogging on building full transparency into their company culture, they build their reach and credibility - with zero dollars invested :)

1. Build brand awareness 

  • People perceive Buffer as a place that is transparent, thus honest and trustworthy. That automatically helps prospects / leads connect on a positive emotional level with their product, which in turn increases long-term conversions.

2. Generate buzz and acquire inbound traffic

  • Although I cannot know for sure, I bet a whole dollar that transparency/culture section on Buffer's blog is the #1 source of traffic they have (or at least it was when they were building their reach). Being very thought-provoking topic, it naturally yields a lot of social media shares, inspires discussion and analysis.

Result: Build reach and credibility

Voilà. It just takes great strategy, tons of energy and a few years... but... there you go :)

There is already quite a few great answers on what platforms/services you can leverage to start building your reach, so I won't go into that.

Title: Can you build an Internet company if you don’t know any programming?
Body:
You can, but you'll wish you did know programming.  You don't need to be a master at it, but ideally you'd know enough to build some quick prototypes.

If you can build a prototype (even if you don't use that code at all in your released product), you'll be able to get it out the door faster and cheaper.  It's much easier for everybody to catch your vision when you can show them what you envision.

When you understand programming, you know the technical trade-offs and make better business decisions.

When hiring, you'll be able to know the engineers that actually know their stuff, rather than the ones that are just a bunch of hot air.  I can't believe how many people fall for guys who act smart by dropping a ton of keywords.

Your engineers will respect you more.  I've been in many groups of engineers where we'd laugh at the ridiculous requests we've gotten.  If you know your stuff, they're more likely to trust your judgment.

It shouldn't be hard to learn.  Pick up a book on web development and just start building.  Don't try to understand everything before you start.  And don't worry too much about doing it "right."

Title: What is the difference between a UX and UI designer and a web designer?
Body:
One of the reason for this question to exist is due to the chaotic way we have for job titles in the design industry, I guess. So it's interesting to have a look at everyone's definitions for those mentioned titles here. And, I'd like to also add mine.

UI Designer (aka. User Interface Designer)

Well, the title literally says it all, this person designs user interface including any kind of visual layer that stands between the user and a product (mostly digital products). The required fundamental knowledge for this position involves understanding of how human use and communicate with (digital) products to create functional and easy to use interfaces combined with a sense of aesthetic.

UX Designer (aka. User Experience Designer)

Perhaps this is the most tricky one which makes it often hard to explain to a layman. A User Experience Designer is the one whose responsibility is to make sure that the overall experiences of the target users while and after using the product is positive and fit close to the target's demands. UX designers create mind maps, user journeys and real world usage scenarios to stimulate how would the target users use the product to create a solution which helps the users to accomplish their goals in the best possible way. Thus, their job is to make a lot of studied assumptions for which they design the solution to test and validate.

One of the most important step of the user experience design process is to study the users whose experiences they're trying to design for. In order to do that, UX designers try to collect as information as possible about the target audiences by conducting interviews, making surveys, quantitative analysis etc. Collecting users data is an on-going process that never ends. UX designers collect and analyze the data constantly to create insights which will be the guideline for everyone else in not just the product team to make design and strategic product decision.

User Experience Designer doesn't necessarily possess visual or graphic design skill set, however, an understanding of psychology and systematic design is a must.

Web Designer

UI designers who're specialized in design and building web user interface. Most of the web design jobs prefer the candidates who know a bit of front-end programming such as HTML/CSS, Javascript to show how the design/prototype would work on screen. The same preference also appears in most UX design job description.

Visual/Graphic Designer

This is basically graphic design or anything that needs a sense of aesthetic. Visual Designer's main job is to make thing look pretty and stylish. Most of the time, this position involves working with things that need to be printed out such as book covers, branding packages, billboards, etc. However, it's not just limited to print material, Visual Designer also creates beautiful digital websites, banners, infographics, etc. At the core, they're best at beautifying stuffs.

Title: User Experience Design: How do you get a job as a designer without going to design school?
Body:
I guess I'm qualified to answer this question though I went to design college, I dropped out after the first year. There're a lot of good answers here already, I just want to add one more perspective to the list.

Sure, you can get a design job without having a degree or academic education. Same thing could be true for programming as well. You just need to show potential employers why and how you are qualified and suitable for the job, which could be done through doing lots of  freelance works or working on your own projects.

However, it's unlikely that you will be able to teach yourself probably if you choose this path. Because a design school may not teach you instantly applicable up-to-date techniques found on most Internet articles, the school will provide you basic knowledge and ground principles which is very important for beginners rather than some quick how-to-do tutorials. So you either have to be very good at self-learning or you need to find a good design mentor.

I dropped out of college because I didn't get the value I want in academic environment. The first thing I did was putting my portfolio together, my resume was quite sufficient for jobs seeking thanked to a lot of freelance works I did during and before college time. I went on a job hunt and got some good offers but finally ended up working as an intern with no salary for a TV channel for kids & teenagers. I decided to do so because I saw the opportunity for me to continue my education with the chief of design team in the channel. The chief was one of the best professionals of the design field in my city. It was working with him that I could grow myself to the best potential. We didn't talk a lot about techniques which you could find easily on the Internet, we often talked about theories, mindsets or how to put yourself in users/audience's shoes to practice user-centric design. All of those things are hard to find learn by yourself or it could take you a lot of times to figure it out on your own. That's why if you aren't into academic education - school or college, you should find yourself a good mentor somewhere to help you to grow fast and compensate for what you might be missing in school.

Also, it's very important for you to learn how to networking and create connections, which is one of the big thing you might miss not going to school. So try to find yourself in some industrial communities and make new relationships, they will be very beneficial in the long run if you need helps or looking for freelance works. Get to know the best persons in the field and follow their works/blogs, it's never a waste to learn from others' experiences.

Title: What is the next trend in UI design after flat design?
Body:
After flat will come material (already has) which is not flat but has depth. Then more depth and bevels and back again. Fashion is driven in circles by two things. The desire of the masses to look like the leaders, and the desire of the leaders to differentiate themselves from the masses. The pace of fashion accelerates, not with innovation, but as the masses get the means to more rapidly appropriate the status symbols of those they envy.

The cycle accelerates until it implodes and spirals off in a different direction entirely. Flat design would have been PERFECT in the early, low bandwidth days of the web. But everyone then wanted to show depth and texture precisely because it was it was difficult to achieve. Once everyone could do it, it became fashionable not to - to show "restraint". Title: What are the best resources for learning bleeding-edge web, UI and UX design?
Body:
The question isn't about the best resources for learning "UX" but rather "bleeding edge" UX. That's really tricky to answer, and I'm not sure anyone here has really addressed it.

The problem is that a person doesn't learn about the bleeding edge of UX until it is already a trend. The bleeding edge is something that you live on. It's a place where group ideation turns interesting ideas into new concepts and the most common phrase is "I think we're close" - in a room with a century of combined professional experience. It gets written up when it works but the cutting room floor looks like a confetti factory.

Bleeding edge UX considers the page refresh a disruptive anti-pattern, for example. It accepts that the pattern exists but finds ways to minimize its effect.

Bleeding edge UX looks for ways to reduce UI pattern interference with the formation of mental heuristics, which is why we have started using bottom navigation as a responsive element instead of just in mobile apps.

Bleeding edge UX is like being a entrepreneur. It's about finding and resolving pain points that have become so accepted that people don't even realize they hurt anymore.

Bleeding edge UX is solving for X in a room full of Ws and Ys. Bleeding edge UX suggests H and is waiting for you to get it. Bleeding edge UX is invisible today but obvious in hindsight. By the time you see the edge the blood is long gone.

Your best resources are conversation and group ideation. Surround yourself with people who are curious and be generous in your approach to the world.

Title: Does being an indie gamedev actually pay the bills?
Body:
I mean, obviously, it depends on what you by "indie" but given what young people on web forums etc. usually mean by "indie" -- i.e. them and their friends putting something together without any external support -- the answer to the question, generally speaking, is no.

It is hard to make money off of a game project even if you successfully complete it. Let's put it this way: it is hard to finish a game, period. It is hard to start your project and somehow come up with the art and write all the code and actually finish it and get it up on the web or in an app store, etc. -- doing so is a real accomplishment if the game is at all non-trivial. Most teams never even make it to the point at which anything is playable much less polished and complete.

Howevever, that said, all things being equal, in terms of paying one's bill the above is far and a way the easy part. Implementation is easy because one can do it if one knows how and one sets one's mind to it and powers through. You can't set your mind to and power through gaining users and getting money, however. If you could every decent programmer in the world would be supporting themselves by writing independent games.

Title: What is being done to make gamedev work easier?
Body:
Aside from general ongoing improvements in technology, the Internet and the growing corpus of industry knowledge and experience: middleware/tooling and digital distribution.

Tools like Unity and its Asset Store, not to mention Unreal/CryEngine are a massive boost to indie/low-budget game dev. The barrier to entry and the learning curve has dropped greatly at the bottom end.

At the other end of the scale, those engines plus myriad tools like PathEngine, ScaleForm, Havok, etc help folks get things done (not to say that AAA game projects have gotten cheaper or easier, they certainly haven't, but a great deal more can be achieved).

The digital distribution thing may not technically be part of the "development" bit, but platforms like Steam (with its Early Access and Greenlight programs) and the huge rise of mobile app stores have greatly enhanced the scope of indie/low-budget game devs. Getting your stuff in reach of the average consumer is entirely doable nowadays (getting them to buy it is another story), as is making sure they have a reasonable chance of installing your latest patches and updates, and flogging them more content via DLC and in-app purchases. Years ago selling your games was a closed shop (ho ho) reserved for big publishers working through largely inaccessible retail markets.

Those same big publishers can also use Steam and app stores to push smaller products out faster, invest in more experimental things that would have been too risky before, avoid physical distribution hassles, keep everyone updated, sell DLC, manage piracy, etc.

Title: Why are so many gamedevs willing to work at such long hours for low pay?
Body:
I've never worked professionally as a game developer, but I've seriously considered working towards it as a career path on many occasions and I assume that some of my motivations are shared by actual professional game devs.

There's an undeniable "cool" factor in getting to program games, especially on next-generation AAA titles. Game programmers get to push technology to its absolute limits for the sheer purpose of spreading joy and blowing minds. A typical AAA game involves the implementation of physics, advanced mathematics, cutting edge graphics, artificial intelligence, networking techniques/algorithms (if it is a multiplayer game), and tons of other fascinating topics. When comparing this to your typical enterprise software, the latter can seem depressingly trivial and mundane.

Personally, the sweet spot for me is working in a software/web-dev job where I get to work on projects that interest me (though perhaps not as much as games interest me), make good money, and work reasonable hours. I still get to pursue my game dev interests and learn lots of cool things in my free time by working on my own indie game projects, but I also get to be comfortable and well-paid and not be exploited.

Fortunately for game developers, the impression I have is that their skillset is generally a superset of what is required to succeed in more generalized software development. Game developers not only have to have strong general programming/algorithmic skills, but also often need to have a very deep understanding in one or more specific aspects of game dev (such as graphics, AI, etc). So I imagine that a game developer who wants to transition to non-game development wouldn't have too much trouble.

Title: If Python "doesn't scale", why is Quora built on it?
Body:
Every (decent modern) language can scale. The difference is in the architecture encouraged by the language, and the complexity of the resulting architecture.

Most of the Python frameworks I've seen are synchronous: A single interaction with a user has to complete before that thread can handle another user. This is true of many other server languages as well: PHP, Java, and Ruby all either encourage or require that behavior.

So to scale vertically (i.e. in a single system) you need to run more threads. But OS threads are high overhead, and task switching will itself eat up much of the system performance.

Languages that encourage asynchronous development, meaning that they can switch between "light" tasks in a single OS thread, can scale vertically to handle far more connections on a single server. Languages that support this mode include JavaScript/NodeJS, Elixir/Erlang, Lua, and Go.

Note that the difference is only relevant for server tasks that aren't processor intensive. If your server is doing a machine learning calculation for every user, "light" threads will not buy you much, if anything.
 
So while the short answer is that Python can scale, for many common workloads a Python backend will require far more horizontal scaling than one that supports "light" threads. I've seen Python workloads take literally 50x as many servers than an equivalent NodeJS backend would require, for instance.

I spoke with a CTO who was spending more than $15k per month for hosting of their Python backend based on a workload that a few $20/month NodeJS servers would have handled without breaking a sweat. They've grown since then and cut their hosting costs drastically.

But again, it depends a lot on what your server is doing. If the architecture is designed well, you can scale just about anything. The easiest way to scale a Python server might be to put it behind a NodeJS server as microservices, but there's always a way.

EDIT: I just came across uvloop: Blazing fast Python networking, which brings fast asynchronous networking to Python. Using that, you could write Python that scales on the order of the other async languages I mentioned. But most Python doesn't use that approach, in my experience.

Title: How useful of a programming language is Go?
Body:
Weirdly and surprisingly useful! I have been known to be critical of Go because of its lack of support for implementing generic data structures, but the truth is, you don’t need that most of the time. When you do need it, would be nice to know that there is a well tested third-party package that does supply what you need, but purpose built-data structures specifically for your usecase are nonetheless typically going to be faster–if you know what you’re doing.

However, for a great majority of problems, which can be solved with dynamic arrays and hash maps (as we’ve learned from Perl, Python, Ruby, JavaScript and many others), Go is a gives you a lot of functionality and great performance in a really simple package.

In a lot of ways, it even feels a bit like a so-called scripting language with the added benefit of static type checking and strict error handling. Programs are typically a little longer in Go than in a dynamically typed language, but they are still much shorter and simpler than programs in languages like Java while offering a similar level of reliability and performance. (perhaps I should qualify that its performance is similar to well-written Java, not the run-of-the-mill, over engineered crap that gives the language the reputation of being slow).

While I tend to personally prefer statically typed functional languages like OCaml and Haskell, I would still be happy to work with Go over many other languages.

Title: Why is Linux so unfriendly?
Body:
As someone who has dabbled in Linux since the turn of the century, I can tell you that it was very unfriendly at one time, but isn’t today.

The main reason people still perceive Linux as unfriendly is because most people have lived their whole life running Windows and/or some version of MacOS, and probably did so on prebuilt computers. All they did was sit down and go. After a while, you get used to the look and feel, and how it works. This is why Microsoft faced a near-revolt when they dramatically changed the desktop paradigm in Windows 8, and then had to backtrack.

You can buy prebuilt PC’s running Linux, but that’s a niche market, and most people who use Linux are enthusiasts who have the technical knowledge to install their own OS. Most people have never even installed Windows themselves, let alone anything else.

The first time I attempted Linux was around 2001, with the old Mandrake distro that was then considered the most user-friendly. I was able to get it installed and running, but it always had problems, even though there was nothing all that unusual about my hardware configuration. The problems were just serious enough to make Mandrake not very much fun to use. I’m sure that an experienced user could have fixed it, but I wasn’t one, and I really didn’t have the time in those days to devote to learning it myself. This was a recurring theme with me and Linux for several years.

Title: What happened to Hadoop?
Body:
Hadoop went through the hype cycle that every other tech product goes through.

  1. First it was an innovation - aka distributed map-reduce that allowed fault-tolerant storage and queries on big-data.
  2. Then the expectations went to an all-time high as it was touted as the replacement for many of the traditional RDBMS tools.
  3. Then the trough of disillusionment as projects started to fail to live up to expectations: primarily because a) Hadoop is not a stable eco-system and b) the skills needed to manage Hadoop (aka Java-based data administrators) are shorter in supply vs. SQL analysts.
  4. Other technologies have come to challenge Hadoop’s use-case - particularly Spark and other in-memory based storage for high-performance analytics and cloud-based SQL databases on AWS/Azure/GCP also provide the fault-tolerant distributed computation that everyone wanted at better prices.

Will it die? Maybe not. But it may continue to live on as a niche technology for specific purposes.

Funny enough, when Hadoop popularity was at an all time high, sometime circa 2016 I posted a humorous take on the google searches for Hadoop and predicted it would die around October 2018. That month was the date that Cloudera and Horton announced their merger. That was for me the bonafide sign that Hadoop commercial market was no longer sustainable.

Data sometimes is scary that way.

Title: As a software engineer, what was the weirdest piece of code you ever saw?
Body:
I spotted a whole subroutine that didn’t necessarily belong to a piece of Python that I was working on.

At this point in upgrading the code, I was running diffs at every modification.

No sooner than I removed the unnecessary code segment, something went screwy with the entire system.

Eventually I figured out that I was causing a seg fault and soft reboot of my QA systems.

Put the code back, and started injecting a lot of print statements with descriptions of what each section of code was doing.

One of those sections of code, produced by the subroutine in question, were assembly lines.

At this point, I’m comfortable enough with the code to understand that I know it’s not compiling and doing stuff on-the-fly, but this section of assembly was necessary. — Still doesn’t make sense. — At least the Python code wasn’t calling an on-the-fly compilation routine from what I could tell. I didn’t know how the system truly consumed the instructions shipped in the package my software was meant to produce.

It was necessary to pass the assembly at that exact point in execution of a number of routines — byte-oriented read of the package produced by the routine. And the assembly was slowly pieced together by the Python subroutine itself. But it always came out the same — the exact same lines, no matter what I threw at it, in the exact same place, injected along the way before pushing the final piece of software to a publication server. (Which my QA systems pulled, tried to load, and then choked on if I removed what I first thought was unnecessary overhead crap from poor/crappy development.)

So, I upgraded the code and left it alone. Along the way, I fired off a few queries about what the deal was. — That there was something unknown, and screwing with it broke things, otherwise, that portion/segment of code was good to go for integration.

Title: What is a software prepared from the C language?
Body:
C is the most commonly used language for programming embedded systems, the others being assembly language (increasingly rare nowadays) and C++. The latter is typically used more for larger systems with microprocessors instead of a microcontroller.

C is also used for programming systems software. The various versions of Linux are mostly written in C. The GNU compiler collection (gcc) is written largely in C, with parts in C++. The reference implementations of Python, Perl and PHP are all written in C.

Title: What are beginner apps that can help you learn programming?
Body:
1. Get yourself a notebook, pen, pencil, ruler and flowchart stencil set. These are better than any apps that will every be written.
  2. Get yourself a book or ebook on drawing flowcharts and truth tables.
  3. Get yourself a toolchain for your computer. This can be Java, Hugs88, GHC, UPC, GForth, Visual Basic, GCC or anything else that exists. It really makes no difference in the end.
  4. Get yourself a book or e-book on that language that contains examples. Get a second book that contains a complete list of commands and functions, if the first book doesn’t have it.
  5. Start with something simple. Writing “Hello, World!” is popular.
  6. Draw a flowchart that shows each action that the program needs to take. If any complex choices are involved, draw a truth table for each one.
  7. Flip through the examples to find out what you need to tell the computer that you’re writing a program and what it needs to do for each action in it. It’s a good idea to read the explanations and other verbiage, but as you get better, you’ll need less and less.
  8. If there are actions for which no example is helpful, use the reference book to find out what the commands are that you need and how they should be written. You should never have to do this step as a beginner.
  9. Test the program.
  10. If it doesn’t work, read more of the verbiage and look at more examples to see what you missed, then fix the program and go back to step 9.
  11. Ok, it works, so make notes on what you had to do that you didn’t expect, what bugs you found, etc.
  12. Turn to a clean double page. This is an absolute rule in science and engineering. The first page is a bother, but you can’t help that. After that first project, everything you do should start on the top of the left page. Even if it wastes space. Clarity is essential, space isn’t. Even if there’s just one word on the last double page, it doesn’t matter. You will waste a lot less trees and a lot less time with this regimen than you will by trying to sort things out later. If you’re doing this at school, expect to get screamed at by staff - just remember that if they’d had better discipline and less lip, they’d not be screaming for a start. Extremely bad practice. They’d probably also know about proper science and engineering disciplines. Do not, however, tell them this. I seem to remember getting some bad reactions.

Title: How can we add C++ to HTML?
Body:
OQ: How can we add C++ to HTML?

You’re probably thinking of webassembly. The layman’s explanation: think of it as a compiled app running within the context of the HTML page. It’s a pretty exciting revolution as far as performance, security, stuff like that.

Webassembly can be built with any language*; for C++, the library is Emscripten. It’s a little complex to learn, but if you already have some C++ skills, it should be straightforward to pick up.

Good luck!

Title: Is there currently a backlash against object-oriented programming in the software development industry?
Body:
Yes, there is a backlash.

It’s a very typical geek response to geeks’ own shortcomings: Rather than look into ourselves to see whether our thinking and presumptions should be brought into question, we seek something external, like technology, to blame.

Most line of business applications are essentially a means to get data back and forth from UIs to relational databases - irrespective of language paradigms. This isn’t necessarily a right or good way to think about (and thus design and code) applications, but it’s the lens that developers look out at the world through. It’s one of those biases that doesn’t get the rigorous inspection that it deserves.

When the mind can’t get beyond data storage (or doesn’t even recognize the existence of this artifice) as the central thesis of application development, it will subvert all technologies to this end.

OO technologies have been subverted to serve data storage. That’s the way that geeks see software development, and geeks - being geeks - are not able to recognize this bias in themselves.

ORM is not OO. But most developers will have gravitated to data storage using objects (because they can’t help themselves), and thus we have ORM. But ORM is a pretty thorough violation of OO. Nonetheless, sooner or later we have to do data storage and retrieval.

If we represent data in an OO language, we’re going to be representing the data with objects. But data is OO-with-an-asterisk. It’s the use of OO that has to violate OO (and other) design principles. Data objects are not supposed to be the center and core of an OO solution. They are the black sheep of the solution. We have to accept that data structures have to exist, and will exist, but we keep them isolated at arm’s length, and don’t let their negative influence to seep into the rest of the design.

Objects are behavioral. The are the doers of things, not the representations of things. When we allow our minds to focus almost exclusively on the task of marshaling data to-and-from storage, we subvert objects to the role of representations. And when that happens, we allow ourselves to abort the learning process that allows us to see what it means when it’s said: Objects are behavioral.

When we use objects in the way that objects are intended, we end up with objects that do things, rather than be things. When our focus is on data - whether consciously or otherwise - we end up with a kind of OO that is far from exemplary of reasonable, good, and effective OO. In effect, when we allow out minds to be fixated on data rather than behavior, we end up with ORM, not OO (even though ORM is constructed of objects and object technologies).

I once heard the statement that, “Objects are just closures”. I think it was on Lambda the Ultimate that I first came across this statement. It’s an apt and accurate description. And it provides guardrails for using OO in a way that OO is effective.

There is a backlash against OO because developers have failed frequently with OO. They’ve failed because they pumped the contents of their minds and their presumptions directly into a text editor without stopping to ever wonder whether they were going in a direction that is the diametric opposite of OO.

There’s a backlash against OO because geeks are blaming the technology (again) rather than wondering whether it’s the shallowness of unquestioned assumption and presumption that’s at fault.

Objects are behavioral. Objects are principally the doers of things, not the data of things. Objects are closures.

Title: How much does web application development cost?
Body:
Web application cost estimation is a thorny issue because clients instantly want to hear an accurate figure, and companies try to explain why it doesn't work like that. Both sides insist they are right. The cost of creating a web app is composed of the number of work hours put into it, multiplied by the hourly rate of your web development team. The number of work hours that your team will need to develop your app will mostly depend on its complexity. Developers in USA, Canada, the UK, and Australia can be hired to make a web app for $80-250/hour.

Eastern Europe, Middle East, and South America come second with $30-110 per hour. The cheaper option is to hire developers from Ukraine for $20-50 or India for $10-80 per hour.

The oversimplified estimations of the three types of projects based on their complexity are given below.

Basic: Pages with static information and it can cost about $3K.

Medium Complexity: Pages with static information, few functional units, and API, third-party integration. it can cost from $10K.

Complex: All from ‘Medium’, Multiple user roles, High user load and Custom statistics. It may cost about $25K.

Title: How do programmers customise their Linux terminal?
Body:
Thanks for the A2A.

There are multiple, pretty much orthogonal ways to make your terminal experience better and more productive:

  • Using an advanced terminal emulator. There are multiple good ones to choose from. Just to name a few: GNOME Terminal, Konsole, Terminology, Final Term (discontinued), Terminator and Terminix. For OS X there’s also iTerm2.
  • Using a terminal multiplexer. Even though you may not need its multiplexing functionality since you already have tabs in the terminal emulator, there’s still a lot it can help with. GNU Screen and tmux are the two popular ones.
  • Using an advanced shell. While most Linux distributions come with GNU bash as the default shell (it’s GNU/Linux, after all), many professionals prefer other shells. The most known ones are zsh and fish. Also, check out xonsh if you like Python.
  • Making use of a plugin framework. zsh and fish come with oh-my-zsh and oh-my-fish, respectively.
  • Using a custom prompt. oh-my-zsh and oh-my-fish already come with a prompt set up in an awesome way. Still you may want to look at Powerline and oh-my-git. The former provides beautiful and highly-functional prompts for bash, tmux, vim and IPython (among other things). The latter is a super-advanced prompt for working with git.
  • Defining and using shell aliases and functions. Most shells, including bash, zsh and fish, let you define and use aliases and functions. Those help you workaround this kind of situations, and they also increase your speed by factoring out common command sequences.
  • Using thefuck. thefuck is a powerful command correction tool. Its GitHub page describes it as “magnificent”, and I tend to agree. Seriously, check it out.

Oh, and there is one more thing. It has always been a dream of mine to have a modern terminal emulator that would work more like an IDE, utilizing graphical capabilities of our hi-res screens for providing a richer environment, in particular, a much more powerful autocomplete. Well, it seems like my dream is coming true, and the project that is making it a reality is called Black Screen. Maybe in the future we’ll have a decent terminal experience right out-of-the-box, without messing with lots of external tools.
